name: Beautiful Array
statement: Stanley defines the beauty of an array $$$a$$$ of length $$$n$$$, which contains non-negative integers , as follows: $$$$$$\sum\limits_{i = 1}^{n} \left \lfloor \frac{a_{i}}{k} \right \rfloor,$$$$$$ which means that we divide each element by $$$k$$$, round it down, and sum up the resulting values. Stanley told Sam the integer $$$k$$$ and asked him to find an array $$$a$$$ of $$$n$$$ non-negative integers, such that the beauty is equal to $$$b$$$ and the sum of elements is equal to $$$s$$$. Help Sam — find any of the arrays satisfying the conditions above.
inputFormat: Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \le t \le 1000$$$). Description of the test cases follows. The first line of each test case contains integers $$$n$$$, $$$k$$$, $$$b$$$, $$$s$$$ ($$$1 \leq n \leq 10^{5}$$$, $$$1 \leq k \leq 10^{9}$$$, $$$0 \leq b \leq 10^{9}$$$, $$$0 \leq s \leq 10^{18}$$$). It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$10^5$$$.
outputFormat: For each test case print $$$-1$$$ if such array $$$a$$$ does not exist. Otherwise print $$$n$$$ non-negative integers $$$a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n$$$ ($$$0 \leq a_{i} \leq 10^{18}$$$) — the answer.
